content.title: Wilson Disease
content.summary: Autosomal recessive disorder of copper metabolism due to ATP7B mutations causing copper accumulation in liver, brain, and cornea, presenting with hepatic, neuropsychiatric, and ophthalmologic manifestations
key_points: ATP7B gene mutation causes impaired copper excretion
Copper accumulates in liver, brain, cornea, kidneys
Kayser-Fleischer rings pathognomonic but not always present
Liver biopsy copper >250 mcg/g dry weight confirms
Treatment: D-penicillamine, trientine, or zinc lifelong
Liver transplant curative for hepatic disease

statement.text: Wilson disease is an autosomal recessive disorder caused by mutations in ATP7B, encoding a copper-transporting ATPase. Defective copper excretion into bile leads to accumulation in liver (hepatitis, cirrhosis), brain (movement disorders, psychiatric symptoms), and cornea (Kayser-Fleischer rings). Diagnosis requires low ceruloplasmin, elevated urine copper, and liver biopsy confirmation. Lifelong chelation therapy or zinc prevents progression; liver transplant is curative.
statement.formal: Wilson Disease = ATP7B mutation + Low ceruloplasmin + High urine copper + Liver copper >250 mcg/g + KF rings

explanation.intuition: Copper is normally excreted in bile. When the copper pump (ATP7B) is broken, copper accumulates like a clogged drain. First it fills the liver, causing hepatitis and cirrhosis. Then it spills into the bloodstream, depositing in the brain (causing tremor, dystonia) and cornea (causing the golden-brown KF rings). Chelation therapy acts like a sponge to pull out the copper.
explanation.key_insight: Always consider Wilson in young patients (<40) with unexplained liver disease, neuropsychiatric symptoms, or hemolytic anemia. Kayser-Fleischer rings are pathognomonic but absent in 50% of hepatic presentations. The Leipzig scoring system integrates clinical and lab findings for diagnosis.
explanation.technical_details: ATP7B is a P-type ATPase in hepatocyte trans-Golgi network that loads copper onto ceruloplasmin and excretes copper into bile. Mutations cause both decreased ceruloplasmin (lack of copper loading) and bile copper accumulation. Copper is cytotoxic via reactive oxygen species generation. Penicillamine chelates copper for renal excretion; zinc blocks intestinal copper absorption.

definitions_glossary.wilson_disease: Autosomal recessive copper metabolism disorder from ATP7B mutations
definitions_glossary.atp7b: Copper-transporting ATPase mutated in Wilson disease
definitions_glossary.ceruloplasmin: Copper-carrying glycoprotein synthesized in liver; low in Wilson disease
definitions_glossary.kayser_fleischer_rings: Golden-brown corneal copper deposits visible on slit-lamp examination
definitions_glossary.penicillamine: Copper chelating agent excreting copper via kidneys
definitions_glossary.trientine: Alternative copper chelator with fewer side effects than penicillamine
definitions_glossary.zinc_therapy: Blocks intestinal copper absorption; maintenance therapy
definitions_glossary.leipzig_score: Diagnostic scoring system for Wilson disease
definitions_glossary.coombs_negative_hemolysis: Hemolytic anemia from copper toxicity without autoantibodies
definitions_glossary.liver_biopsy_copper: Definitive test; >250 mcg/g dry weight diagnostic

pathophysiology.mechanism: ATP7B mutations impair copper incorporation into ceruloplasmin and biliary copper excretion. Copper accumulates first in liver (hepatocyte injury via oxidative stress), then redistributes to brain (basal ganglia, putamen), cornea, kidneys. Liver disease ranges from asymptomatic transaminitis to fulminant hepatic failure. Neurologic disease presents with tremor, dystonia, dysarthria, parkinsonism. Psychiatric manifestations include depression, psychosis, personality changes.
pathophysiology.genetic_basis: Autosomal recessive; ATP7B gene chromosome 13q14; >500 mutations identified

clinical_presentations.hepatic: Asymptomatic transaminitis, chronic hepatitis, cirrhosis, fulminant hepatic failure
clinical_presentations.neurological: Tremor, dystonia, parkinsonism, dysarthria, ataxia, chorea
clinical_presentations.psychiatric: Depression, anxiety, psychosis, personality changes, cognitive decline
clinical_presentations.ophthalmologic: Kayser-Fleischer rings (95% with neuro disease; 50% hepatic-only)

chelation.penicillamine: Initial therapy 1-2 g/day; side effects include bone marrow suppression, nephrotoxicity, lupus-like syndrome
chelation.trientine: Alternative chelator; fewer side effects; preferred if penicillamine intolerant

zinc.mechanism: Blocks intestinal copper absorption via metallothionein induction

liver_transplant.indication: Fulminant hepatic failure, decompensated cirrhosis unresponsive to medical therapy

treatment_options.monitoring: 24-hour urine copper, free copper, liver enzymes; compliance critical

definition.@value: Autosomal recessive disorder of copper metabolism causing hepatic, neurologic, and psychiatric disease

clinical_pearls: Always consider Wilson in patients <40 with unexplained liver disease
KF rings absent in 50% of hepatic-only cases
Coombs-negative hemolysis with acute liver failure is classic
Neurologic symptoms may worsen initially with penicillamine
Siblings of affected patients need screening

sources.source: EASL Clinical Practice Guidelines: Wilson disease. J Hepatol. 2012
